The quintessential Central Anatolian town with a mainly conservative population, Çankırı, home to about 70,000 people, is one of the smallest provincial capitals in Turkey. Although it lies close to both the geographical and the political centre of the country (i.e.,
), the main feel of the place is

. As one writer from Ankara (Nihat Genç, often known for his controversial views) puts it, Çankırı is possibly what Ankara would look like, had it not been declared the capital of the country and received the large government investments, which helped it become the modern metropolis that it is today.
